holdings.libraryName: University of London King's College London Library

bookInfo.notes: An abridgment of John Shirley's translation (first published in 1683)of Geronimo Fern'andez's 'Historia del valeroso e invencible Principe don Belianis de Grecia'. The initial leaf contains woodcut illustrations.

titleGroup.fullTitle: The honour of chivalry, or the famous and delectable history of Don Bellianis of Greece. Containing, The Valient Exploits of that Magnanimous and Heroick Prince, Son unto the Emperor Don Bellaneo of Greece. Wherein are described, the Strange and Dangerous Adventures that befel him: With his Love towards the Princess Florisbella Daughter to the Soldan of Babylon. Translated out of Italian.
titleGroup.displayTitle: The honour of chivalry, or the famous and delectable history of Don Bellianis of Greece. Containing, The Valient Exploits of that Magnanimous and ...
titleGroup.uniformTitle: Historia del valeroso e invencible Principe don Belianis de Grecia. English

pageContent.sectionHeader: THE INTRODUCTION.

CHAP. I. How the Emperor Don Bellaneo (Father to Don Bellianis) Married to the beautiful Clarinda, Daughter to Trolejano King of Spain; and of the Birth of Don Bellianis of Greece; and of a strange ...
CHAP II. How the Emperor departed in quest of his Son Don Bellianis; and of the strange and dangerous Adventure of the Discovered Castle.

CHAP. III. How Don Billianis departed from the Cave, and by what strange Adventure he and Don Arsileo were Knighted, with the brave and dangerous Fight between the two Princes and the Knights of the ...

CHAP. IV. Of the Fight between the Emperor and the Princes, against Don Gallaneo and his Men; and how Don Bellianis and his Company departed undiscover'd who they were; and what happen'd to him and ...
CHAP. V. What happen'd to Don Bellianis and his Companions, with Duke Alsyron, Sir nam'd the Courteous; and of the Adventure of the Bridge.
CHAP. V. What happen'd to Don Bellianis without the City of Perlepolis, and how he deliver'd two Damsels from certain Knights, and whence they were; and how he flew the Dragon of the Riphean Wood.
CHAP. VI. How Don Bellianis made his Escape, out of the Tower, in Disguise; and borrowing Armour of Don Contumeliano of Phnicia return'd unknown into the City; and of the Terrible Fight with the ...
CHAP. VII. Of the Marriage of Duke Alsiron with the Princess Persiana; and what Strange things happenn'd in the Juseings.
CHAP. VIII. How the knight of the Crowns was known to be the Emperor, Don Bellianeo and his Companion to be Sabiam of Trebento: And of the Emperor's going to the Valley of the Three Fountains to ...
CHAP. IX. What the Sage Friston did to get into his Custody the Princess Florisbella; and what Don Bellianis did for her Deliverance, in the Adventure of the Tent.

CHAP. X. What passed between the Sultan of Babylon and the Knight of the Bassilisks, and with the Princess Florisbella: And of Don Bellianis's succouring Don Br anel and Don Clarineo at the Siege of ...

CHAP. XI. How Don Bellianis and the Prince of Numydia, Don Beltazona, set forward on the Adventure, in search of the Inchanted Island, and how they fought with several Knights and Giants, and rescued ...

CHAP. XII. How the Sultan, Don Bellianis, and the Prince of Numydia, arrived in Persia; and how they understood of the Intention of the Emperor of Trebizon, to besiege Babylon: And how in a Battle ...
CHAP. XIII. Of Don Bellianis's arrival at Babylon, and of the Discourse between him and the Sultan.
CHAP. XIV. Of the Marriage of Don Bellianis to the Princess Florisbella.
CHAP. XIV. A Description of the inchanted Castle, and the Adventures of several Knights thereupon.
CHAP. XV. How the Princess Florisbella was delivered of a Son and a Daughter, and how they b were convey'd away by Inchantment.
CHAP. XVI. Of the Grief for the Loss of the young Prince and Princess; and how Don Bellianis, and his Peerless Consort, were comforted by a Letter from the Sage Beliona
CHAP. XVII. How the Prince of the Cape-Island fell in Love with the Princess Mattarosa, and upon her Refusal, convey'd her away by Force, and how she was rescued by the Valiant Don Bellianis.
